Posts.Content: Where around the Boston area are there any prostate cancer detection dogs?... _ _ _ _ _ as indicated in the article... _ _ _ _ _ by Angela Zimm Canines’ Cancer-Sniffing Snouts Showing 90%-Plus Accuracy [google... Canines’ Cancer-Sniffing Snouts Showing 90%-Plus Accuracy] Taverna’s finding comes at a time when use of standard PSA testing for prostate cancer is being challenged as not accurate enough, with false positives leading to unnecessary treatment. In 2012, the Preventive Services Task Force, which reports on medical issues to the U.S. Congress, recommended that healthy men shouldn’t be screened for prostate cancer using PSA tests after research showed that false positive rates of men tested may be as high as 80 percent. Volatile Compounds When dogs sniff for cancer, they are detecting the chemicals emitted by a tumor. These chemicals are referred to as volatile organic compounds, or VOCs. VOCs have been found in the breath of lung cancer patients and colon cancer patients, as well as in the urine of prostate cancer patients. _ _ _ _ _ and the research reported in... _ _ _ _ _ The Journal of Urology Volume 191, Issue 4, Supplement, Page e546, April 2014 PD19-01 PROSTATE CANCER URINE DETECTION THROUGH HIGHLY-TRAINED DOGS’ OLFACTORY SYSTEM: A REAL CLINICAL OPPORTUNITY [google... Prostate Cancer Urine Detection Through Highly-Trained Dogs' Olfactory System] Gianluigi Taverna Milan, Italy Lorenzo Tidu Grosseto, Italy Fabio Grizzi, Guido Giusti, Mauro Seveso, Alessio Benetti, Rodolfo Hurle, Silvia Zandegiacomo, Luisa Pasini, Alberto Mandressi, Pierpaolo Graziotti Milan, Italy DOI: Digital Object Identifier link available via google Abstract Full Text Article Outline Introduction and Objectives Methods Results Conclusions Introduction and Objectives The analysis of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in urines is a promising approach to cancer detection. Here, we establish the level of accuracy at which a rigorously trained canine olfactory system can recognize specific prostate cancer-VOCs in urine samples, thus reducing unnecessary prostate biopsies, and pinpointing patients at high-risk for prostate cancer. Methods A total of 677 subjects were investigated. All the subjects included in the study were placed in one of two main Groups: Prostate Cancer Group (n = 320) and Control Group (n = 357). Prostate Cancer Group includes patients with PC ranging from those at very-low risk to metastatic PC. Control Group includes a large and heterogeneous cohort of healthy subjects or patients affected by non-neoplastic diseases or non-prostatic tumors. Each patient's clinical status and therapeutic regiment was known. We took into consideration all predictive values currently used in the clinical practice for prostate cancer management. Two dogs and a full-time, highly specialized, multidisciplinary team was dedicated. We have standardized a “work training” procedure and eliminated any possible olfactory interference. Each test was carried out blindfold. Results The dogs achieved the following performances: Dog 1: sensitivity 100%, specificity 97.8%, accuracy 98.9%. Dog 2: sensitivity 98.6%, specificity 95.9%; accuracy 97.3%. When considered together, Dogs 1 + 2, we found an accuracy of 98.1% with a sensitivity of 99.2% and a specificity of 97.1%. Whether excluded the female control sub-groups we found that Dog 1 achieved a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 97.9%, while Dog 2 a sensitivity of 98.6% and a specificity of 94.5%. When evaluating the wrongly detected cases no differences were found between epidemiological, clinical or histopathological characteristics. Conclusions The present study first demonstrates that a trained canine olfactory system detects specific PC-VOCs in urine samples from a large number of patients with PC at different stages and risks versus a heterogeneous control group, which is unthinkable in current clinical urological practice. Thanks to the early intuition, we have definitely turned what used to seem a myth into a real clinical opportunity. _ _ _ _ _ see also report in Reuters Health by Bridgett Novak [google... Dogs can sniff out prostate cancer in urine] _ _ _ _ _ In Wikipedia... electronic nose
Posts.Title: Where around Boston are there any prostate cancer detection dogs? Volatile Compounds

Posts.Content: Before biopsy, google... prostate cancer non-invasive test Difficult that is looking for a second opinion and delay for sorting out any and all non-invasive testing or going ahead with biopsy. For example . 3T MP MRI Blue Laser 3 Tesla Multi-Parametric Magnetic Resonance Imaging, google... 3T MP MRI . MiPS Urine Test University of Michigan Mi-Prostate Score, google... MiPS urine test . or other non-invasive testing before biopsy could be available at another clinic or via another doctor.

Posts.Content: Current reading... 1 Steven Lamm MD, Herbert Lepor MD, Dan Sperling MD Redefining Prostate Cancer 2013 Spry Publishing Lamm, a practicing internist, is Director of the Men's Health Center at New York University Medical Center. google... Steven Lamm 2 H. Gilbert Welch MD MPH, Lisa M. Schwartz MD, Steven Woloshin MD Overdiagnosed, Making People Sick in the Pursuit of Health 2011 Beacon Press Welch writes about risk communication, google... H. Gilbert Welch 3 Richard J. Ablin PhD DSc, Ronald Piana The Great Prostate Hoax, How Big Medicine Hijacked the PSA Test and Caused a Public Health Disaster 2014 Palgrave Macmillan Ablin discovered PSA prostate specific antigen in 1970, google... Richard Ablin 4 Rick Redner, Brenda Redner RN/BSN I Left My Prostate in San Francisco----Where's Yours?, Coping with the Emotional, Relational, Sexual, and Spiritual Aspects of Prostate Cancer 2013 WestBox Press Rick Redner MSW is a former medical social worker. google... Rick Redner 5 Pamela Ellsworth, MD 100 Questions & Answers About Prostate Cancer, Third Edition 2013 Jones & Bartlett Learning Ellsworth is an Associate Professor of Urology, Surgery, and Pediatrics at Brown University. google... Pamela Ellsworth 6 Richard Besser, MD Tell Me The Truth, Doctor, Easy-to-understand Answers To Your Most Confusing and Critical Health Questions 2013 Hyperion Besser is former acting director of the American Centers for Disease Control and Prevention CDC and Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry ATSDR. google... Richard Besser, 7 Jack McCallum The Prostate Monologues, What Every Man Can Learn from My Humbling, Confusing, and Somertimes Comical Battle with Prostate Cancer 2013 Rodale McCallum is Visiting Writer-in-Residence at Muhlenberg College Media & Communication Department. google... Jack McCallum 8 Gerald Chodak, MD Winning the Battle Against Prostate Cancer, Get the Treatment that is Right for You, Second Edition 2013 Demos Medical Publishing Chodak blogs Controversies in Urology. google... Gerald Chodak 9 Ming Zhou MD Uropathology, High-Yield Pathology 2012 Elsevier Saunders 10 Robert O. Petersen MD Urologic Pathology, Third 3rd Edition 2009 Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Wolters Kluwer Health It is a great difficulty, reading these writings, looking though the books for any and all medical centers that make available Non-invasive tests for patients seeking second opinion without delay before biopsy! If any of you kind folks out there should by coincidence happen upon medical centers that make available Non-invasive tests for patients seeking a 2nd opinion without delay before biopsy, please send along information...
Posts.Title: Current reading: Redefining Prostate Cancer. Overdiagnosed. The Great Prostate Hoax.

Posts.Title: Better detection

Posts.Content: a) Sorting out professional medical literature? Any hints, tips, pointers how you kind folks out there might sort out the professional medical literature listed at the lower left?... of the InfoGraphic for the new detection technique at http://sperlingprostatecenter.com/wp...eLaserIG-1.jpg Depending on what's available locally, I prefer to get any and all non-invasive or less-invasive testing before getting biopsy or cystoscopy without going to New York City. b) Other clinics? Where else around North America can you get the new detection technique?... indicated at that InfoGraphic besides New York City? The medical literature listed without live links in the lower left of the InfoGraphic are http://www.manogram.org/facts2.html http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/760288 http://prostatecanceruk.org/information/diagnosis http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21385484 http://www.brazjurol.com.br/january_...ikos_87_93.pdf http://www.scpr.org/news/2012/12/10/...-testing-pros/ http://www.cancernetwork.com/prostat.../10165/2137328 http://prostate-cancer.org/decisiona...c/trus-biopsy/ http://prostate-cancer.org/decision-...here-to-start/ http://prostate-cancer.org/PDFs/Is14-1_p3-9.pdf https://www.google.com/search?q=deci...ate-cancer.org http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/f.../detection/PSA After the faulty second last link listed at the lower left of the InfoGraphic I put two of the related pages... and a search string. c) Unique software? Anything really all that unique about the software used at that New York clinic?... d) Other radiologists' software? Any other clinics have new advanced software for radiologists' analyses?
Posts.Title: Any hints tips pointers how you kind folks out there sort out medical literature?...

Posts.Content: What do abbreviations CT, GH, MH, UA reference?... in GH: CT and Cytology were normal. No GH in 6 years, no MH since 2003. Will forego cystoscopy unless new GH or MH on UA.

Posts.Content: Particularly with elevated PSA prostate specific antigen for the ages in the 60s when cancer hasn't been diagnosed yet, would any non-invasive or less-invasive testing be considered before invasive cystoscopy or before invasive biopsy?... for example a) Check blood markers. b) Free-to-total PSA ratios. c) The 4K score https://www.google.com/search?q=4kscore d) Prostate Health Index. e) Imaging, Spectrographic MRI. f) Color Doppler ultrasound. g) etc. h) Or ....?
Posts.Title: What non-invasive testing should be considered before cystoscopy or biopsy?

Posts.Content: What non-invasive or less invasive testing should be considered before the invasive cystoscopy or before the invasive biopsy?... for example a) Check blood markers before the biopsy b) Free-to-total PSA ratios c) The 4K score https://www.google.com/search?q=4kscore d) Prostate Health Index e) Imaging, Spectrographic MRI f) Color Doppler ultrasound before the biopsy!
Posts.Title: What non-invasive testing should be considered before cystoscopy or biopsy?

Posts.Content: What non-invasive or less invasive testing should be considered before the invasive cystoscopy or before the invasive biopsy?... for example a) Check blood markers before the biopsy b) Free-to-total PSA ratios c) The 4K score https://www.google.com/search?q=4kscore d) Prostate Health Index e) Imaging, Spectrographic MRI f) Color Doppler ultrasound before the biopsy!
Posts.Title: What non-invasive testing should be considered before cystoscopy or biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by a Senior User Re: Interesting Study While this is something that may or may not be true. It is interesting none the less. _ _ _ _ _ > By Michelle Roberts. Prostate cancer 'may be a sexually transmitted disease' _ _ _ _ _ > This latest research is not the first to suggest a link between trichomoniasis and prostate cancer. A study in 2009 found a quarter of men with prostate cancer showed signs of trichomoniasis, and these men were more likely to have advanced tumours. _ _ _ _ _ > Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences _ _ _ _ _ > Trichomonas vaginalis homolog of macrophage migration inhibitory factor induces prostate cell growth, invasiveness, and inflammatory responses > Olivia Twu, et al... > Published online before print May 19, 2014, Digital Object Identifier doi: 10.1073/pnas.1321884111 > PNAS May 19, 2014 > Infections in men may result in colonization of the prostate and are correlated with increased risk of aggressive prostate cancer. google... Infections in men may result in colonization of the prostate A thought experiment. The Strategy of getting tested TOGETHER BEFORE sex for A VARIETY OF STIs then making an INFORMED decision, google... tested together before
